items.title: Ford ends F-150 Lightning after $19.5B loss

featured_image.name: Ford To Stop Making All Electric F-150 Truck, In Shift To Hybrids

items.description:
Ford Motor announced Monday it is discontinuing production of the all-electric F-150 Lightning pickup truck and taking a $19.5 billion charge as the Detroit automaker pivots away from large battery-electric vehicles toward hybrids and more affordable EVs[1][2][3].

The company, which has lost $13 billion on electric vehicles since 2023, will replace the Lightning with an extended-range electric vehicle (EREV) featuring a gasoline generator that provides an estimated 700-mile range[1][2][4]. Production of the current Lightning ended this year after just three-and-a-half years on the market[5][6].

items.title: Tiny autonomous robots solve 40-year robotics challenge

featured_image.name: Penn and Michigan Create World's Smallest Programmable ...

items.description:
Researchers at the University of Pennsylvania and University of Michigan have unveiled the world's smallest fully programmable, autonomous robots, according to studies published December 15 in Science Robotics and Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences[1][2][3]. The microscopic swimming machines, measuring 200 by 300 by 50 micrometers—smaller than a grain of salt—can independently sense temperature, process information, and operate for months while costing just a penny each[4][1][5].

The robots represent what researchers describe as a solution to a 40-year challenge in robotics. "We've made autonomous robots 10,000 times smaller," said Marc Miskin, assistant professor in electrical and systems engineering at Penn and senior author of both papers[1][5]. "That opens up an entirely new scale for programmable robots."

items.title: ISIS ideology drove Bondi Beach attack, Australian PM says

featured_image.name: AUSTRALIA-ATTACK-BONDI

items.description:
Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese confirmed on Tuesday that the father-son duo behind the Bondi Beach massacre that killed 15 people were motivated by Islamic State ideology, as investigators revealed the suspects traveled to the Philippines last month and possessed homemade explosives alongside ISIS flags[1][2][3][4][5].

The declaration came nearly 48 hours after Sajid Akram, 50, and his son Naveed Akram, 24, opened fire on a Hanukkah celebration at Sydney's iconic beach on Sunday evening. "It would appear that this was motivated by Islamic State ideology," Albanese told national broadcaster ABC on Tuesday morning[1][6][7]. Federal Police Commissioner Krissy Barrett officially classified the attack as "a terrorist attack inspired by Islamic State"[4][8][9].

items.title: Alps could lose 100 glaciers per year starting in 2033

featured_image.name: Record number of glaciers will disappear from Alps soon

items.description:
The European Alps could lose more than 100 glaciers annually starting as early as 2033, marking the highest rate of glacier disappearance ever recorded in the region, according to a study published Monday in Nature Climate Change[1][2][3][4].

The research, led by glaciologist Lander Van Tricht of ETH Zurich, analyzed more than 200,000 glaciers worldwide and introduces the concept of "peak glacier extinction"—the point when the annual loss of glaciers reaches its maximum[2][5][3]. For the Alps, this critical threshold arrives earlier than any other major glacier region, occurring between 2033 and 2041 depending on warming scenarios[3][4][6].

items.title: CoreWeave loses $33B as AI bubble fears grip investors

featured_image.name: Exclusive | CoreWeave's Staggering Fall From Market Grace ...

items.description:
CoreWeave shares plummeted approximately 8% to $72.36 on Monday, extending a brutal selloff that has erased more than $33 billion in market value since the AI data center provider reached its June peak[1][2]. The company, which went public at $40 per share in March, has now lost over 60% of its value from its all-time high of $187[1][3].

The decline comes as Wall Street grows increasingly skeptical about whether massive AI infrastructure investments can deliver promised returns. CoreWeave's troubles have intensified broader concerns about a potential AI bubble, with investors questioning the sustainability of capital-intensive business models that rely on aggressive debt financing[4][5][6].

items.title: US military kills eight in latest Pacific vessel strikes

featured_image.name: US military kills four in latest strike on boat in the Caribbean

items.description:
The US Southern Command conducted lethal strikes on three vessels in international waters in the eastern Pacific on Monday, killing eight people in the latest operation of a campaign that has claimed at least 95 lives since September[1][2][1].

The strikes, carried out by Joint Task Force Southern Spear under the direction of Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, targeted vessels that intelligence officials said were transporting narcotics along known drug trafficking routes[1][3][1]. The attack comes three days after Admiral Alvin Holsey, who commanded US Southern Command and reportedly clashed with Hegseth over the legality of military operations in the region, formally retired and transferred command to his deputy[4][5][6].

items.title: Global stocks fall ahead of key economic data and central bank decisions

featured_image.name: Stocks slide as investors on edge ahead of data, central bank meetings

items.description:
Stocks across Asia and the United States declined Monday and Tuesday as investors adopted a defensive stance ahead of crucial economic reports and a wave of central bank policy decisions that could shape the trajectory for interest rates in 2026.

The S&P 500 slipped 0.16% to 6,816.34 on Monday, while the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.59% to 23,057.41, pressured by continued weakness in artificial intelligence stocks[1][2]. The Dow Jones Industrial Average eased 0.09% to 48,416.57[1][2]. Asian markets extended losses Tuesday, with Japan's Nikkei 225 down 1.27% and South Korea's Kospi falling 0.75%[3][4].

items.title: Seoul court to rule on Yoon obstruction charges Jan. 16

featured_image.name: Police detect signs of records of Yoon Suk Yeol's secure phone ...

items.description:
A Seoul court announced Tuesday it will deliver its verdict on ousted President Yoon Suk Yeol's obstruction and related charges on January 16, concluding a case separate from his ongoing insurrection trial over last year's failed martial law declaration[1][2][3][4][5].

The Seoul Central District Court's Criminal Division 35, led by Judge Baek Dae-hyun, said the ruling must come before a January 19 deadline mandated under special counsel law, which requires first-instance verdicts within six months of indictment[1][5]. Yoon was indicted on July 19 by the special counsel team investigating the December 2024 martial law crisis[5][6].

The announcement came as special counsel Cho Eun-seok concluded his six-month investigation Monday, presenting findings that Yoon had plotted martial law since at least October 2023 to eliminate political opponents and consolidate power[7][8][9]. Cho's team indicted 24 individuals total, including Yoon and five former cabinet members, on insurrection-related charges[10][7][8].

items.title: Broadcom shares tumble in worst slide since 2020

featured_image.name: Broadcom Follows Oracle in Letting Down AI-Focused Investors

items.description:
Broadcom shares extended their decline Monday, closing down 5.6% at $339.86 and marking the chip manufacturer's steepest three-day drop since March 2020[1][2][3]. The selloff wiped out more than $300 billion in market value—roughly equivalent to the entire valuation of rival Advanced Micro Devices—and allowed Meta Platforms to reclaim its position as the sixth-largest U.S. company by market capitalization[4][2].

The decline comes despite Broadcom reporting fiscal fourth-quarter results that exceeded Wall Street expectations. Revenue climbed 28% year-over-year to $18.02 billion, while adjusted earnings per share of $1.95 beat the consensus estimate of $1.86[5][6][7]. The company's artificial intelligence revenue surged 74% to $6.5 billion and is projected to double to $8.2 billion in the current quarter[5][8].

items.title: Russia open to Ukraine EU membership in peace deal, U.S. says

featured_image.name: GERMANY-US-UKRAINE-RUSSIA-CONFLICT-DIPLOMACY

items.description:
Russia has indicated willingness to accept Ukraine's membership in the European Union as part of a peace deal to end the war, U.S. officials said Monday following two days of intensive negotiations in Berlin[1][2][3][4][5]. The development comes as negotiators reached consensus on roughly 90 percent of issues in a 20-point peace plan, marking what officials called "substantial progress" toward ending the nearly four-year conflict[1][3][6].

U.S. special envoy Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner, President Donald Trump's son-in-law, spent over eight hours in direct discussions with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and European leaders on December 14-15[7][3][6]. The talks produced an agreement on NATO Article 5-like security guarantees for Ukraine, which U.S. officials described as the "platinum standard" that would require Senate approval[7][2][8][9].

"We believe the Russians, in a final deal, will accept all these things which allow for a strong and free Ukraine. Russia, in a final deal, has indicated they were open to Ukraine joining the EU," a senior U.S. official said, speaking anonymously due to the sensitive nature of negotiations[2]. While Russia has previously stated it does not object to Ukraine's EU membership, U.S. officials characterized Moscow's current position as a notable concession within the broader peace framework[3][4][5].

items.title: Over half of peer reviewers now use AI tools in their work

featured_image.name: AI peer reviewers are fine with AI-fabricated papers - C&EN

items.description:
More than half of peer reviewers are now using artificial intelligence tools in their work, according to a new survey that has prompted calls for updated publishing policies to ensure responsible and transparent use of the technology in scientific publishing.

A whitepaper released Thursday by Frontiers, an open-access publisher based in Switzerland, found that 53% of reviewers have used AI during peer review, with nearly one-quarter reporting increased usage over the past year[1][2][3]. The findings, based on a survey of 1,645 active researchers worldwide conducted earlier this year, reveal that many scientists are using AI tools "in contrast with a lot of external recommendations of not uploading manuscripts to third-party tools," according to Elena Vicario, Frontiers' director of research integrity[4].

items.title: Interstellar comet makes closest approach to Earth Friday

featured_image.name: New images show an interstellar comet that will soon make its closest approach to Earth

items.description:
An interstellar comet discovered this summer will swing within 167 million miles of Earth on Friday, offering astronomers their best opportunity to study the rare visitor from beyond our solar system before it races back into the cosmos[1][2][3][4].

Comet 3I/Atlas, traveling at 130,000 miles per hour, represents only the third confirmed interstellar object to pass through our solar system[5][4][6]. The comet will reach its closest approach to Earth on December 19 at approximately 1.8 astronomical units—nearly twice the distance between Earth and the sun—posing no threat to our planet[4][7][8].

items.title: BlackRock, World Bank lead Ukraine rebuilding plan

featured_image.name: Ukraine Secures $7.9B World Bank Support for 2025 Recovery ...

items.description:
BlackRock and the World Bank are spearheading a large-scale financial and rebuilding plan for Ukraine as part of ongoing peace negotiations, U.S. officials announced Monday following two days of intensive meetings in Berlin with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky and European leaders[1][2].

BlackRock CEO Larry Fink has assembled a team working pro bono alongside World Bank President Ajay Banga to develop a recovery framework addressing Ukraine's post-war economic viability, according to senior U.S. administration officials[1][2][3]. The discussions mark a critical juncture in efforts to end the nearly four-year conflict while ensuring Ukraine's long-term stability, with reconstruction costs estimated at $524 billion over the next decade[4][5][6].

items.title: Interstellar comet to pass Earth Friday amid debate over unusual features

featured_image.name: NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope Revisits Interstellar Comet

items.description:
As interstellar object 3I/ATLAS prepares for its closest approach to Earth on Friday, the cosmic visitor has ignited both public fascination and scientific scrutiny while displaying features that challenge conventional comet behavior.

The object will pass within approximately 167 million miles of Earth—nearly twice the sun's distance—posing no threat to the planet, according to NASA [1][2][3]. Yet its unusual characteristics, including a persistent "anti-tail" pointing toward the sun and a striking color transformation from red to green, have fueled debate about its nature and origins.

items.title: CIA nuclear device lost in Himalayas in 1965 remains missing

featured_image.name: How Did the C.I.A. Lose a Nuclear Device in the Himalayas ...

items.description:
A covert Cold War mission to spy on China ended in failure when American and Indian climbers abandoned a plutonium-powered surveillance device on one of the world's highest peaks in 1965. Six decades later, the nuclear generator remains buried somewhere in the Himalayan ice, according to a New York Times investigation published Sunday[1][2].

The device, containing nearly a third of the plutonium used in the Nagasaki atomic bomb, disappeared from Nanda Devi mountain and has never been recovered despite multiple search operations[1][3][2]. Its disappearance has sparked environmental fears and renewed calls from Indian officials for a recovery mission, as the device lies near glaciers that feed the Ganges River, a water source for hundreds of millions of people[1][4].

items.title: EPFL launches software to run AI models locally without cloud

featured_image.name: Do we really need big data centers for AI?

items.description:
Researchers at École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne have released software that could disrupt the artificial intelligence industry's dependence on massive cloud data centers, offering organizations a way to deploy powerful AI models entirely on local machines while keeping sensitive data private.

The software, called Anyway Systems, was announced December 14 by EPFL's Distributed Computing Laboratory and has already been spun off into a startup[1][2][3]. The technology allows users to download open-source AI models and run them on networks of ordinary computers without sending any data to third-party cloud services—a capability that challenges the infrastructure model currently dominated by major technology companies.

items.title: US says 90% of Ukraine peace issues resolved after Berlin talks

featured_image.name: European leaders agree Ukraine security guarantees should include European-led peacekeeping force

items.description:
United States officials said Monday that approximately 90 percent of outstanding issues between Russia and Ukraine have been resolved following intensive negotiations in Berlin, marking what they described as a breakthrough toward ending the nearly four-year conflict.

The assessment came after two days of talks between Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and Trump administration envoys Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner[1][2][3]. "We've moved considerably closer in narrowing the issues between the Ukrainians and the Russians," one US official told reporters[2][4]. However, the official acknowledged that territorial concessions remain the primary obstacle to a final agreement[1][5].

items.title: Interstellar comet approaches Earth amid global defense drill

featured_image.name: 3I/Atlas interstellar comet will make its closest approach to Earth this week

items.description:
An interstellar comet will pass within 167 million miles of Earth on Friday, Dec. 19, as space agencies from more than 23 nations conduct the largest planetary defense drill in history[1][2][3].

The comet, known as 3I/ATLAS, was discovered on July 1, 2025, by the ATLAS telescope in Chile and represents only the third confirmed interstellar visitor to our solar system[4][5][6]. The object originated beyond our solar system and is traveling through on a hyperbolic trajectory, meaning it will never return[7][2].

items.title: Scientists decode how iron minerals trap carbon in soil

featured_image.name: Iron minerals' hidden chemistry explains how soils trap carbon

items.description:
Northwestern University engineers have decoded the nanoscale chemistry that allows iron oxide minerals to lock away vast amounts of carbon in soil, potentially keeping it sequestered for centuries and preventing it from entering the atmosphere as greenhouse gases[1][2][3].

The study, published today in Environmental Science & Technology, reveals that ferrihydrite—a common iron oxide mineral found in soils—employs multiple chemical strategies to capture organic carbon, challenging long-held assumptions about how these minerals interact with organic matter[1][2].

items.title: DOJ faces Friday deadline to release Epstein files

featured_image.name: When will the Epstein files be released? Here's the latest - USA Today

items.description:
The Department of Justice faces a Friday deadline to release decades of government records related to convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, marking a pivotal moment in efforts to uncover the full extent of his criminal network. Under the Epstein Files Transparency Act, signed into law by President Donald Trump on November 19, the DOJ must publicly disclose its vast archive of documents by December 19[1][2][3][4][5].

The law, which passed the House 427-1 and received unanimous Senate approval, requires the release of internal correspondence, investigative materials, court records, victim statements, flight logs, seized electronic devices, and documentation of Epstein's 2019 death in custody[1][2][6]. Three federal judges have already granted DOJ motions to unseal grand jury materials from investigations into Epstein and his convicted associate Ghislaine Maxwell[6][7][8][9].

items.title: Nvidia launches open-source AI models, acquires SchedMD

featured_image.name: Nvidia briefly on track to become world's most valuable company ever

items.description:
Nvidia launched a new generation of open-source artificial intelligence models on Monday and announced its acquisition of AI software provider SchedMD, as the chipmaker pushes to establish itself as a leading provider of open-source AI amid intensifying competition from Chinese tech firms[1][2][3][4].

The California-based company, which has become the world's most valuable publicly traded company, unveiled its Nemotron 3 family of models designed for writing, coding, and other tasks[2][3][5]. The smallest model, Nemotron 3 Nano, is available immediately, while two larger versions—Nemotron 3 Super and Nemotron 3 Ultra—will launch in the first half of 2026[1][2][3].

items.title: Alps glaciers to hit peak extinction rate by 2033

featured_image.name: The Alps set to lose a record number of glaciers in the next decade, study warns

items.description:
The European Alps are on track to experience their highest rate of glacier disappearance within the next eight years, with over 100 glaciers set to vanish annually by 2033, according to a study published Monday in Nature Climate Change[1][2][3][4][5][6].

The research, led by glaciologist Lander Van Tricht at ETH Zurich, analyzed more than 200,000 glaciers worldwide and introduced the concept of "peak glacier extinction"—the point when the annual loss of glaciers reaches its maximum[1][3][6]. For the Alps, this critical threshold arrives earlier than any other major glacier region, occurring between 2033 and 2041 depending on warming scenarios[4][5][6].

Under current climate policies steering the world toward a 2.7 degrees Celsius temperature rise above pre-industrial levels, only about 110 glaciers would remain in Central Europe by 2100—a mere 3% of today's total of approximately 3,000[4][6]. At 4 degrees of warming, that number plummets to around 20[1][4]. Even iconic formations like the Rhône Glacier would shrink to tiny remnants or disappear completely, while the mighty Aletsch Glacier would fragment into smaller parts[4].

items.title: Russia may accept Ukraine's EU membership in peace deal

featured_image.name: Want Ukraine in the EU? You'll have to reform the EU, too.

items.description:
Russia has indicated it may accept Ukraine joining the European Union as part of a peace agreement to end the nearly four-year war, US officials disclosed Monday, as intensive negotiations in Berlin concluded with claims of substantial progress toward ending the conflict[1][2][3][4].

The development emerged after Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy held two days of talks with President Donald Trump's special envoy Steve Witkoff and Trump's son-in-law Jared Kushner in the German capital. The discussions lasted more than five hours on Sunday and approximately 90 minutes on Monday[5][6][7][8].

items.title: Glacier loss to peak by 2040, with thousands vanishing yearly

featured_image.name: World heading toward ‘peak glacier extinction' with up to 4,000 set to disappear a year

items.description:
The world's glaciers are disappearing at an accelerating pace, with new research warning that up to 4,000 glaciers could vanish each year by mid-century, threatening water supplies for billions of people and erasing landscapes that have shaped cultures for millennia.

A study published Monday in Nature Climate Change examined all 211,000 glaciers on Earth and found that the rate of glacier loss will reach a critical peak between 2040 and 2055, depending on how much the planet warms[1][2]. Currently, approximately 750 to 1,000 glaciers disappear annually, but that figure is projected to triple or quadruple within two decades[3][4][5].

Under current climate policies, which put the world on track for 2.7 degrees Celsius of warming above preindustrial levels, around 3,000 glaciers would vanish every year between 2040 and 2060[1][6][2]. If warming reaches 4 degrees Celsius, annual losses could peak at 4,000 glaciers in the mid-2050s—a rate three to five times higher than today[2][1]. Even if warming is limited to 1.5 degrees Celsius as outlined in the Paris Agreement, roughly 2,000 glaciers would still disappear annually by 2041[1][5].

items.title: Russia rejects key proposals as Berlin peace talks continue

featured_image.name: Zelenskyy offers to drop NATO bid in exchange for security guarantees, refuses to cede land

items.description:
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky resumed negotiations in Berlin on Monday with U.S. envoys and European leaders, but prospects for a swift end to the war dimmed as Russia signaled it would reject key elements of any revised peace plan[1][2][3][4].

The talks, now entering their second day, brought together Zelensky, U.S. special envoy Steve Witkoff, and Jared Kushner, President Donald Trump's son-in-law, following a five-hour session on Sunday that Witkoff described as yielding "a lot of progress"[1][3][5]. Later Monday evening, German Chancellor Friedrich Merz was set to host British Prime Minister Keir Starmer, French President Emmanuel Macron, and heads of NATO and the European Union for broader consultations on Ukraine's security[6][7][8].

items.title: Ukraine, US resume Berlin talks as Zelenskyy drops NATO bid

featured_image.name: Ukraine-US talks to continue in Berlin as Ukraine willing to drop Nato ambitions – Europe live

items.description:
Ukraine and US officials resumed peace negotiations in Berlin on Monday, seeking to broker an end to Russia's war after five hours of talks the previous day yielded what envoys described as substantial progress[1][2][3].

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy met with US special envoy Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner, President Donald Trump's son-in-law, for a second consecutive day of discussions centered on a 20-point peace framework[1][3][4]. Witkoff said Sunday that "a lot of progress was made" during the initial meetings[1][2][3]. European leaders including UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer, French President Emmanuel Macron, and German Chancellor Friedrich Merz were set to join the talks later Monday in a show of solidarity with Kyiv[5][6][7].

The negotiations come after Zelenskyy offered to drop Ukraine's long-held ambition to join NATO in exchange for binding security guarantees from Western nations[1][8][9][10]. "From the very beginning, Ukraine's desire was to join NATO; these are real security guarantees," Zelenskyy said in a WhatsApp chat with reporters Sunday[9][11][12]. "Some partners from the US and Europe did not support this direction."

items.title: Scientists capture first image of atomic oxygen in water

featured_image.name: Water's enigmatic surface: X-ray snapshots reveal atoms ... - Phys.org

items.description:
Researchers have achieved the first direct imaging of individual atomic oxygen dissolved in water, using an ultrafast laser technique that reveals the highly reactive atoms persist far longer and travel deeper into liquids than previously thought—a finding that challenges existing scientific models and could advance applications from medical sterilization to industrial chemistry.

The study, published November 23 in Nature Communications, used femtosecond two-photon absorption laser-induced fluorescence to capture images of ground-state oxygen atoms in water[1][2]. According to the research team, measurements showed oxygen atoms survive for tens of microseconds and penetrate hundreds of micrometers into the liquid, with concentrations near the water surface reaching approximately 10¹⁶ atoms per cubic centimeter[3][1].

items.title: Global stocks rise ahead of central bank decisions

featured_image.name: Stock futures are little changed as big week of economic data kicks off: Live updates

items.description:
European and US stock markets climbed Monday as investors entered the final full trading week of 2025 bracing for a series of major central bank decisions and critical economic data releases delayed by the recent government shutdown.

The pan-European STOXX 600 rose 0.4% by morning trading, with London's FTSE 100 gaining 0.5%, Germany's DAX advancing 0.3%, and France's CAC 40 climbing 0.4%, according to multiple reports[1][2][3]. US stock futures pointed higher, with S&P 500 futures up 0.4% and Dow Jones Industrial Average futures rising 0.5%[4][5][6].

The gains followed Friday's sharp selloff, when the S&P 500 fell 1.07% and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 1.69% after Broadcom's disappointing profit margin outlook reignited concerns about overinvestment in artificial intelligence technology[7][8]. Asian markets declined Monday, with Japan's Nikkei 225 down 1.3% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng falling 1.4%[2][9].

items.title: Roomba maker iRobot files for bankruptcy, to be sold to Chinese firm

featured_image.name: Robot Vacuum Roomba Maker Files for Bankruptcy After 35 ...

items.description:
iRobot, the company behind the iconic Roomba robot vacuum, filed for pre-packaged Chapter 11 bankruptcy on December 14 in Delaware, marking the end of an era for the 35-year-old American robotics pioneer[1][2][3]. The Bedford, Massachusetts-based company will be acquired by Shenzhen PICEA Robotics Co., its secured lender and primary contract manufacturer, in a transaction that will wipe out existing shareholders[4][2][5].

Under the restructuring support agreement, Picea will receive 100% of iRobot's equity, while all issued and outstanding common stock will be cancelled with holders receiving no recovery on their investment[4][2][5]. The company listed estimated assets and liabilities in the range of $100 million to $500 million in court filings[6]. iRobot expects to complete the court-supervised process by February 2026, after which it will become a private company wholly owned by Picea and delist from Nasdaq[4][2][5].

items.title: Australia to tighten gun laws after Bondi attack kills 15

featured_image.name: Australian Prime Minister Albanese proposes tougher national gun ...

items.description:
Australia moved swiftly on Monday to tighten its already strict gun control laws after a terror attack at Sydney's Bondi Beach killed 15 people during a Hanukkah celebration, marking the nation's deadliest mass shooting since 1996[1][2][3][4][5][6][7][8][9].

Prime Minister Anthony Albanese convened an emergency National Cabinet meeting where state and territory leaders agreed to implement what experts describe as the most significant overhaul of Australia's firearms regime in nearly three decades[6][10]. The proposed measures include restricting gun licenses to Australian citizens only, limiting the number of firearms an individual can own, and introducing periodic license reviews[1][6][11][12][10][13].

"People's circumstances can change. People can be radicalised over a period of time. Licences should not be in perpetuity," Albanese told reporters Monday[14][3][7][15][12][16].

items.title: Spain fines Airbnb $75M over unlicensed rentals

featured_image.name: Spain fines Airbnb $75 million for unlicensed tourist rentals

items.description:
Spain has imposed a €64 million ($75 million) fine on Airbnb for advertising unlicensed tourist rentals, escalating the government's crackdown on short-term accommodation platforms amid an acute housing affordability crisis.

The Consumer Rights Ministry announced Monday that 65,122 advertisements on the platform violated consumer protection rules, including listings without valid licenses or with license numbers that did not match official registries[1][2][3]. The penalty, which equals six times the illegal profit Airbnb earned from these listings, represents one of the largest consumer rights fines in Spanish history[2][4].

items.title: Iranian rial hits record low as sanctions deepen crisis

featured_image.name: Iran currency falls to record low against dollar as tensions with US mount

items.description:
Iran's national currency collapsed to a historic low on Monday, with the rial trading above 1.3 million to the US dollar in Tehran's currency markets[1][2][3][4]. The sharp decline, which came less than two weeks after the currency first breached 1.2 million per dollar, underscores the mounting economic pressure facing the Islamic Republic as international sanctions tighten and regional tensions persist[2][5].

The currency's freefall is compounding already severe inflationary pressures. Food prices surged 66% year-over-year through November, with bread and cereals up 100% and fruits and nuts climbing 108%[6]. Annual inflation reached 40.4% in November and could accelerate further following a gasoline price increase implemented December 13[6][7].

items.title: Interstellar comet to pass Earth Thursday with rare anti-tail

featured_image.name: 3I/ATLAS Update: Harvard Physicist Puzzled by Alien Comet's Striking Color Change — It Glows Green

items.description:
As interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS approaches its closest encounter with Earth on Thursday, December 19, astronomers worldwide are focused on a rare celestial feature that has persisted for months: a luminous anti-tail pointing toward the sun[1][2][3]. The object will pass within approximately 170 million miles of our planet—nearly twice the distance between Earth and the sun—posing no threat while offering researchers an opportunity to study material from beyond our solar system[4][5][6].

The anti-tail, first identified in Hubble Space Telescope images on July 21, was still visible in observations from November 30, and recent telescope images from Thailand confirmed its continued presence through mid-December[1][7][3]. Unlike conventional comet tails that stream away from the sun, pushed by solar radiation and wind, this sunward-pointing structure has proven remarkably persistent across thousands of observations[1][8][3].

items.title: Markets await central bank decisions amid delayed US data

featured_image.name: Stock futures are little changed as big week of economic data kicks off: Live updates

items.description:
Global financial markets held in a cautious range Monday as investors braced for a pivotal week of central bank policy decisions and delayed U.S. economic data that could reshape expectations heading into the new year.

European stocks edged higher, with the STOXX index gaining 0.6%, while S&P 500 futures rebounded 0.4% after U.S. equities slumped Friday on concerns about artificial intelligence valuations[1][2]. Asian markets proved less buoyant, with MSCI's Asia-Pacific index shedding 1.2% amid renewed property sector worries in China[1].

The Japanese yen strengthened 0.6% to 154.955 per dollar after a closely watched survey showed big manufacturers' business sentiment hit a four-year high in the three months to December[1][3]. The result reinforced expectations that the Bank of Japan will raise its policy rate by 25 basis points to 0.75% at its December 18-19 meeting, marking the first increase since January[4][5][3]. A strong majority of economists—90% in a recent Reuters poll—predict the move[5].

items.title: Little Foot fossil may be unknown human ancestor species

featured_image.name: Painstaking study of 'Little Foot' fossil sheds light on ...

items.description:
One of the most complete ancient human ancestor skeletons ever discovered may belong to a previously unknown species, according to research that challenges the classification of a fossil unveiled eight years ago.

A study published in the American Journal of Biological Anthropology suggests the Little Foot skeleton, found in South Africa's Sterkfontein caves, does not fit into either of the two species to which it has been attributed since its public debut in 2017[1][2][3]. The research, led by Dr. Jesse Martin from La Trobe University in Melbourne, Australia, marks the first challenge to the fossil's species classification since it was unveiled[3][4].

"We think it's demonstrably not the case that it's A. prometheus or A. africanus," said Martin, who also holds a postdoctoral research fellowship at the University of Cambridge[3]. "This is more likely a previously unidentified, human relative."

items.title: European stocks climb ahead of central bank decisions

featured_image.name: European shares gain on boost from banks, Fed cut optimism

items.description:
European markets opened higher Monday as investors positioned themselves for a pivotal week featuring multiple central bank policy decisions and delayed U.S. economic data releases.

The DAX in Germany climbed 0.4%, France's CAC 40 gained 0.4%, and the FTSE 100 in the U.K. rose 0.5% in early trading[1][2][3]. Banks and energy stocks led the gains, helping the region recover from Friday's tech-driven selloff on Wall Street[4][5].

items.title: Korea Zinc to build $7.4B US smelter for critical minerals

featured_image.name: Korea Zinc to build $10.9 trillion integrated smelter in US - CHOSUNBIZ

items.description:
Korea Zinc announced on Monday it will proceed with a $7.4 billion smelter project in the United States to produce critical minerals, sending the company's shares surging 11% in morning trading[1][2][3][4]. The world's largest zinc smelter said the U.S. government requested the facilities to address expanding global supply chain risks and rising demand for strategic minerals[2][3][5].

The South Korean company established a joint venture called "CrucibleMetals" on December 11 and will raise $1.94 billion through the venture, with remaining funds secured through U.S. government policy financing, subsidies, and financial investor loans[6]. The smelter will produce zinc, lead, copper, precious metals, and strategic minerals including antimony, germanium, and gallium, with commercial operations starting gradually in 2027[2][5][6].

items.title: EU's Kallas vows no summit exit without Ukraine funding

featured_image.name: Kaja Kallas: 'We should stop pretending that Russia is negotiating ...

items.description:
European Union foreign policy chief Kaja Kallas declared Monday that EU leaders will not leave this week's summit without securing funding for Ukraine, warning that rewarding Russian aggression would only invite more conflicts[1][2][3].

Speaking ahead of the European Council meeting scheduled for December 18-19 in Brussels, Kallas emphasized that security guarantees for Ukraine must include "real troops, real capabilities," not merely symbolic commitments[4][5]. The summit comes as Ukraine faces a critical funding shortfall, with experts warning Kyiv could run out of cash by spring 2026 without additional support[6][7][8].

items.title: Asian markets tumble on tech sell-off, weak China data

featured_image.name: Asian markets drop with Wall St as tech fears revive

items.description:
Asian stocks fell sharply on Monday as technology shares tracked U.S. losses and disappointing Chinese economic data deepened concerns about slowing growth in the world's second-largest economy.

Japan's Nikkei 225 dropped 1.2% to 50,220.15, dragged down by heavy losses in AI-linked stocks[1][2]. SoftBank Group, an investor in OpenAI, plunged 6.3%, while Advantest, a chip-testing equipment maker and Nvidia supplier, slid 5.8%[1][3]. The tech-heavy Hong Kong Hang Seng shed 0.8%, and South Korea's KOSPI declined 1.4%[2][4].

The sell-off followed a sharp 5.1% drop in the Philadelphia SE Semiconductor index on Friday, as investors retreated from technology stocks amid worries about an AI bubble[1][5][6]. The selling pressure intensified after Broadcom and Oracle delivered mixed earnings guidance earlier in the week, raising questions about returns on massive AI investments[2][7][4].

items.title: China Vanke debt crisis rattles Asian markets

featured_image.name: China Vanke's paths to avoid default narrow after failing to win ...

items.description:
Asian stocks tumbled Monday as China Vanke's looming bond default heightened concerns about the world's second-largest economy, casting a shadow over year-end trading as major central banks prepare crucial rate decisions this week.

MSCI's broadest index of Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan dropped 1.2%, with South Korean equities falling as much as 2.7% despite being among the world's best-performing markets this year[1][2][3]. The selloff came after bondholders rejected China Vanke's proposal to delay a 2 billion yuan ($283 million) bond payment due December 15, leaving the state-backed developer with a five-business-day grace period to avoid default[4][5][6].
